repnme.cdata!:
Lithuania - Second Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Structural Adjustment Project
            (SAL-II) for Lithuania had a satisfactory outcome with a
            substantial development impact.  Project sustainability is
            highly likely, with satisfactory performances by both the
            Bank and the Borrower. The main objectives of SAL-II were
            achieved, although problems arose in the implementation of
            some second tranche reforms, resulting in delays in second
            tranche release.  The operation was cancelled in June 2002
            upon request of the Government, with the second tranche
            undisbursed.  Lessons learned include the following.  The
            traditional two-tranche structure of SAL-II worked well to
            anchor reforms across governments.  Very strong initial
            ownership, combined with a broad consensus across political
            parties was important.  The comprehensive and ambitious
            scope and content of SAL-II worked well.  High quality
            supervision is important for any operation with continuity
            as one component of quality supervision; and conscientious
            efforts made to maintain continuity in the task team.  There
            is a high payoff to analytic work.  In view of the
            difficulties in implementing the privatization of Lithuania
            Gas, a systematic review of privatization of infrastructure
            and other enterprises operating in highly imperfect markets
            is needed, drawing on the Bank's recent experience.
            SAL-II had an important impact on the institutional
            development agenda, by drawing on on-going technical
            assistance, and supporting subsequent institutional reforms.
            Where relevant projects are in place, there can be strong
            synergies between the project and a SAL.  Finally, the
            financial terms and structure of this loan (a
            Euro-denominated, fixed spread loan, payable in 11 years
            with a bullet principal repayment) reflect the wider range
            of financing options that the Bank began offering clients in
            the mid-1990s.

repnme.cdata!:
Lithuania - Second Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Loan Project
            will support the government of Lithuania implement the
            structural reform program, aiming at reducing poverty,
            through a rapid economic growth, within a macro-financial
            stability setting. The reform program will correct
            macroeconomic imbalances, and implement reforms in budget
            management, pensions, and social assistance, private sector
            development, and in the energy, and agricultural sectors.
            The project will contribute to positive private foreign
            borrowing, as well as to the country's eventual
            accession to the European Union. However, given the
            macroeconomic scenario, the lack of creditor confidence
            would raise real interest rates, placing added pressure on
            enterprise financing, and, public debt difficulties would
            threaten further increases in budgetary arrears, risking
            recovery growth, macro financial vulnerability, and poverty
            increases. In addition, political risks are associated with
            the upcoming parliamentary elections. Nonetheless,
            widespread perception, and commitment by all political
            parties to reforms, seem substantial, and risks will be
            mitigated through regular consultation by the Bank, with a
            broader group of civil society outside the government, donor
            coordination, and regular supervision.
